sleep: Studies show that consistently sleeping less than 7 hours per night is associated with memory loss and cognitive decline. (Source: NIH, 2020)
Irregular sleep patterns can increase risk of depression, anxiety, and metabolic disorders. (Source: Harvard Medical School, 2019)
Deep sleep helps clear waste products from the brain, reducing the risk of Alzheimer's disease. (Source: National Institute on Aging, 2021)
People who sleep fewer than 6 hours a night have a 20% higher risk of heart disease compared to those who sleep 7-8 hours. (Source: European Heart Journal, 2011)
Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule improves the body's natural circadian rhythms, boosting energy and focus. (Source: Sleep Foundation, 2022)
exercise: Just 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise per week can reduce the risk of depression by 26%. (Source: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, 2018)
Exercise improves the production of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), a protein linked to memory and learning. (Source: Frontiers in Neuroscience, 2019)
Strength training twice a week can significantly lower the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. (Source: Mayo Clinic, 2020)
Exercising outdoors can enhance mood and reduce feelings of tension and anger more than indoor exercise. (Source: Environmental Science & Technology, 2011)
Late-night exercise may delay melatonin production, making it harder to fall asleep. (Source: Journal of Physiology, 2019)
